Award.AwardTitle: High Energy Physics Research at CMS and D-Zero Collider Experiments
Award.AbstractNarration:
The physics program at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, Geneva, Switzerland is in full operation, now delivering proton-proton collisions at 8 TeV collision energy. The SUNY at Buffalo group is a member of the CMS experiment which is currently in an intense data-taking phase for 2012, and which will segue into an analysis and upgrade phase during the period 2014-1015. While the Fermilab Tevatron has ceased operations, nevertheless significant data remains to be analyzed from the experiments. The SUNY at Buffalo group continues to play an important role in the analysis of data from the D0 experiment.

The proposed program concentrates on finding answers to fundamental questions about the Electroweak symmetry breaking and on searches for physics beyond the Standard Model (SM). One aspect of the research is to search directly for Higgs particles at the CMS and D0 experiments, and to search for evidence of new heavy vector bosons at CMS. Another aspect involves the study of SM processes such as the associated production of vector bosons with bottom and charm quarks which constitute backgrounds to Higgs boson searches in various decay channels. The discovery of the Higgs boson or a new heavy vector boson would be a major breakthrough in our understanding of fundamental properties of matter, while any deviation from the SM prediction could manifest presence of New Physics.

The SUNY at Buffalo group is also making important technical contributions to the CMS Experiment, particularly the operations and upgrade of the Forward Pixel Detector project. The proposed research program building upon the group's success and expertise in Forward Pixel Detector commissioning and operation, in jet calibration techniques at hadron colliders, and in software and physics analysis.

The broader impact of the proposal fosters collaboration between the SUNY Buffalo group members and high school teachers and their students through the group's QuarkNet Center and through Masterclasses. These open up possibilities for non-traditional participants to come in close contact with fundamental research at the energy frontier in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SUNY at Buffalo High Energy Physics Experiment group is a member of the D0 (Fermilab) and CMS (LHC) collaborations. For this grant period, 2012-2015, our group contributed in a number of the D0/Tevatron legacy analyses based on the full data set collected by the experiment. These included publications on improved physics objects (b-/c-quark jets, electrons and photons) reconstruction with the D0 detector, precise measurements of vector bosons (Z/g) production in association with heavy flavor (b-/c-quark) jets and an evidence, with a significance of 3.3 standard deviations, of a Higgs-like particle production.

In the CMS experiment, the group contributed to developments for the software, detector/reconstructed objects calibration, physics analyses and Forward Pixel (FPix) tracking detector upgrade. For the latter, as the LHC increases the luminosity, the current FPix detector cannot cope with the increased data rate. Therefore, it is being replaced during the extended end of year shutdown between 2016 and 2017. Our group has been responsible, and successfully accomplished, various tests of a High Density Interconnect circuits that provide signal and power distribution for the readout chips.

Our group is the main contributor to the CMS effort to calibrate hadronic jets. These are signatures of quarks and gluons created in proton-proton collisions at LHC. Quarks and gluons are copiously produced at LHC. Precise determination of their energy and momenta is of utmost importance for measuring properties of elementary particles, as well as for making new discoveries.

Using CMS data, we have searched for a new particle, Z' which is heavier counterpart of Z-boson -- one of the carriers of for Electroweak interactions. In new theories, Z' particle can decay to top-antitop pairs, and therefore can be detected as a bump structure in top-antitop invariant mass spectrum. So far we have found no evidence for Z' particle. Higher energies and larger datasets of LHC will allow us to probe high mass region for Z' production.
